abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Climate Change
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) Project for Brazil were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was low, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the Government of Mexico (GoM) was, and
            continues to be, fully committed to its climate change
            adaptation and mitigation agenda. This DPL supports
            Mexico's program, and the country is increasingly
            recognized as an international leader in this area.
            Ownership at different levels of government has proven to be
            a driving force for success. An integrated country strategy,
            in which climate change programs and policies are addressed
            throughout with a full range of instruments, creates a
            virtuous framework for addressing the challenges. Granted,
            not all clients can support the number and diversity of
            operations and instruments that have been focused on climate
            change as that of the Mexico program. But it is the
            consistency with which the issue reappears in the Mexico
            partnership program (driven in large part as a reflection of
            the client's commitment), with a diversity of
            investment and policy operations not only cross-sectoral
            (such as this DPL) but sectoral as well, that has led to a
            highly focused and effective engagement. There are more
            unknowns than knowns in the policy and science of climate
            change, so technical assistance and a knowledge intensive
            engagement are especially important.
